text.title: Send Books to Someone in Prison

p.s: If you know someone who is in prison , giving them access to books can immensely help them pass the time , continue to learn and think , and just cheer them up .

Although many prisons only allow books to come from authorized vendors such as book stores or prisoner support organizations such as the Prisoner 's Literature Project , some will allow individuals to send books as well .

item.s: Look up the prison online .
See if there is any information online regarding restrictions , sending information , packaging information , or a mailing address for the prison .
If you are in contact with the prisoner you would like to send books to , he or she may also have information for you .

figure.rend: Send Books to Someone in Prison Step 1.jpg

item.s: Know the prisoner 's ID number as it needs to go on the first line after the prisoners name in order for them to get the books .
The address label must list the name and ID number for the prisoner , the name of the prison , and the prison 's mailing address , which is either the location of the prison or a PO Box .

figure.rend: Send Books to Someone in Prison Step 2.jpg

item.s: Check for the prison regulations on sending things to inmates .
Many prisons have regulations limiting number of books that can be sent , restricting books with sex scenes , not allowing used books , or not allowing hardcover books .
These restrictions vary from place to place and even prison to prison , so be sure to check first .
If there are none present , look for a telephone number to call or email address to email the prison .

figure.rend: Send Books to Someone in Prison Step 3.jpg

item.s: Telephone or email them if you do n't find details .
Consider finding out the following :

figure.rend: Send Books to Someone in Prison Step 4.jpg

item.s: Explain that you would like to send books to a prisoner
Explain who you are and your relationship with the prisoner
Explain what the books are
Ask if this is permitted and if so , what restrictions are in place , if any
Confirm a postal address and any packaging requirements
If you get a positive answer , follow the instructions that were given to post your books or other reading material .

figure.rend: Send Books to Someone in Prison Step 5.jpg

item.s: If you get a negative response , do n't give up yet .
There are still several options to consider :

figure.rend: Send Books to Someone in Prison Step 6.jpg

item.s: Write to an association that helps prisoners , such as the Prisoner 's Literature Project , being sure to include the name , location , and ID number of the prisoner in your letter .
Contact any educational institution that is in contact with and aids prisoners .
Ask the prisoner you are sending books to for more information on restrictions or which vendors they may know are authorized .
Many prisons only allow books to come from an authorized vendor such as a book store or organization .
If you are not allowed to send books as an individual , ask which vendors will be allowed to bring books into the prison and contact those vendors .
Remember that prisons are worried about security .
For these reasons they may require paperbacks only , new books only , or have a limit on the number of books that can be sent at a time .
If you go through a service that specializes in books for prison inmates , they will likely already have a good grasp of what titles are allowed and which are not .
They will already have in stock titles that are sure to be approved .
Be sure to carefully follow all restrictions that are in place , as well as putting the prisoner 's ID number on any packages or letters .
Even a small mistake in following restrictions can cause all your books to be destroyed or sent back .
